content: a first-class these might not look like much but in all honesty they are
probably my favorite bits of terrain I've built in like several months
hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts I absolutely love these things why well I think they are the perfect
balance of effort versus reward they were super simple to put together
and in the end I think they look dope as hell I'm aware that as a terrain builder
I often make a lot of decisions that sacrifice how good or how durable
something is or how nice it looks in order to achieve techniques that are
faster easier and more approachable and this is especially true when I'm
building stuff for videos so it's really nice when I can still have things that
are approachable and easy to do without making those sacrifices and these are
the perfect example of that working I'm also really happy with the paint job on
these often times my paint jobs are just kind of good enough to get the job done
they're okay but they're rarely something that I'm proud of and often
there's something that I'm a little bit nervous to put on the internet for
hundreds of thousands of people but you know what the paint job on these it
looks good I'm happy with it I'm proud of it and I leaned on my airbrush to do
it because I'm learning that that airbrush allows me a lot of freedom to
do more creative and dynamic paint jobs with very little skill but of course you
wouldn't have to do that I've made like 150 build videos where I painted things
with craft paint and a brush and you could apply those same techniques here
if you don't want to go the airbrush route while the final product looks like
the skulls are made of plaster or solid stone or something in reality they're
just the cheapest hollow Halloween skulls you can get I bought a
bag of like a dozen of these for maybe two dollars a few years ago and they
come in super handy all the time I really just needed the face portion and
thankfully the plastic is so soft and thin that it's about as easy as it gets
to cut with an exacto knife all I had to do was grab a chunk of XPS foam and cut
some stone pillars I quickly decided that I didn't want the foam carving to
look well you know like the weight it always looks when you carve rock from
foam it has a recognizable look I wanted something
that had a bit more of a refined texture so I turned to another method instead of
cutting and carving I just scraped the blade across the foam this creates a
really nice layered look it's really not hard to do
all you have to be mindful of is creating lines in interesting directions
and getting them to line up from side to side I realized I could actually get
both of my stones out of just this one first piece so I cut it in half of
instead of creating a second one I thought they would look better if they
were lower and each angled in a bit of a different way attaching the skulls was a
simple matter of hot gluing them in place
the only real trick here is making sure the skulls are as flat as possible if
they're projecting a bunch they could look kind of goofy you want to imply
that they were carved out of the stone and if they're sticking way out well
it's gonna look like they're mounted to the stone rather than being part of it I
prepared some MDF bases and made some final adjustments to the carving before
attaching them in order to really sell the look I cut off a big chunk of one of
them including some of the skull I really wanted to make these look like
they were carved from one chunk of stone and this would really help with that the
secret to making the two pieces unified was modeling paste you could use a
variety of things for this epoxy putty x' plasters hot glue whatever but I
think modeling paste is the easiest to work with in this application you can
apply it pretty thin and it was really easy to sculpt in a way that mimic the
texture on the foam an important thing to notice is that I applied the paste to
most of the smooth surfaces of the skulls I didn't just want to hide the
seams I really wanted to continue that texture across and over as much of the
skulls as possible this is a big reason that the final product actually looked
kind of believable I decided to use modeling paste to cover the bases as
well and I wouldn't actually say this is normally the best choice but I'm really
low on sculpting mold which would be my go-to here and my tub of modeling paste
was starting to get a bit hard and I doubt on the top layer so I figured
why not just use it up here is a good way to get rid of some of that material
that was starting to go bad and while that paste was still uncured I added
some chunks of foam as well as some gravel to make a bit of rubble and
debris from the crumbling stone pillars instead of coating the foam in mod podge
to harden it like I normally do I decided to apply Vallejo ground texture
to the whole piece my hope was that it would make the foam really hard while
also adding a little bit more texture and cohesiveness to the skulls in the
stone I was also able to use it to add a more dynamic and natural texture to the
bases the stuff dries really fast so I could quickly move on to painting I
gotta say I'm absolutely in love with what this coating accomplished it really
did everything I wanted I'm super impressed with how much it harden the
foam now obviously with the texture it's got like some fine sand in it it's not
gonna work on all projects but for stone fan-friggin'-tastic again i got a wax
poetic about airbrush painting here I've painted hundreds of things with craft
paint and brushes and I have a ton of videos showing me do that there's
nothing wrong with those methods you can totally get acceptable results that way
but with a quick zenithal Prime and a few coats of inks hey man I just can't
get over how good it looks with so little skill required the airbrush was
really the magic ingredient for me as a painter I've never been willing to put
in the time required to get really good at brush painting and using the airbrush
kind of lets me skip that effort and get something that looks pretty good without
all that practice and effort and I honestly I just really wish I had
started using this tool sooner I used to kind of dislike the painting portion of
building but doing this method has really made it become my favorite part
of the whole process I just find it so much easier to get a refined look
because it's quick I feel more comfortable exploring more adventurous
color schemes these if I was painting by brush I'd
probably stick to tans and Grey's but here I felt liberated to experiment with
mossy greens Browns and even a bit of red which I think gives the piece of far
more realistic stone color and when it came to dry brushing on some tan to
highlight the edges I was actually kind of nervous to overdo it because I was so
happy with where these rat and I sometimes put on too much paint when dry
brushing I think this was the most cautious dry brushing I've ever done and
I was rewarded for being patient and using almost no paint the effect is
subtle but any more I think would have ruined the pieces well not ruin them
it's just paint like I could have fixed it but any more paint on the dry brush
wouldn't have looked as good and I actually think I could have just left
the basis as is that Vallejo ground texture paint it up look just fine and
it would be a really nice durable base option but I'd be remiss if I didn't add
some sort of flocking and I have this woodland Scenic's foliage that is meant
for making trees I bought it years ago to make bushes and rather than just
being ground up texture or foam or whatever it's sort of made into a sheet
it's kind of like a little net so it's great for creating plant life that's
growing up vertical surfaces for the rest I just used a mixture of really
fine turf and tea bag fillings the last step was just to blast it with a bit
more Brown ink to tone down the colors of the flocking and the tea like I said
at the start these little pieces may not look like much but they are in my
opinion the best thing I've made in a long time they might be small they might
not be complicated but they're incredibly effective I think they look
more professional than a lot of the things they make and they're really
durable at the same time that's a hard thing to achieve often if you want
something to look more realistic you sacrifice durability the more detailed
the more fragile especially when it comes to things like flocking but these
things will hold up you could totally just throw them in a bin and transport
them no problem and they look good if I were to create a big tables worth of
scatter terrain in one thing I think I'd be going with a lot of the
techniques that I tried out on these so what do you guys think let me know in
the comments section below if you liked this video hit that like
button or the dislike button thumbs up thumbs down it doesn't matter
both helped the video and helped the channel in the exact same way if you
want to pick up any tools or supplies for your hobby needs you're not sure
what to get or where to get it check out black magic crafts dot CA I've curated
an extensive essential equipment page where I link to all of the stuff that I
use and explain it why use it what it is and that way you can understand what the
heck you're shopping for especially if you're just starting out and if you
really enjoy these videos that I make each and every week and you want to help
me keep making them the best way you can do that is by supporting the channel on
patreon it's because of patreon that I have the resources to make a weekly
crafting video it's pretty ridiculous to think that I can actually spend my
full-time efforts doing this and one of the reasons the main reason is because
of the support of people on patreon and if you join up buck a month you get
access to the discord server that's full of awesome crafters and if you join it
the fellowship level you get access to the private Facebook group that is a
really good resource full of other people who are interested in this hobby
if you have a question or you're having a hard time or something you can post it
there and people are gonna help you out really fast it's also a place where you
can directly tag me for help and there's a nice little bonus
patreon supporters get to see these videos a few days early that's how you
get those comments that are older than the video it's always funny people are
confused how did this video just get published an hour ago but there's a
comment from three days ago that's why because a lot of folks are watching
these like two days early that's it for this week guys Cheers I'll see you again
next week
